Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Rockhurst University (RU) and Loyola University Maryland (Loyola) are collaborating to create three multi-week upper-division active learning physics modules in fiber optics and light delivery, nuclear physics and nuclear medicine, and pressure in the human body that relate physics principles to medicine. The modules can enhance student learning through their implementation in a Physics of Medicine (POM) Program currently in place at RU and in development at Loyola. The target audience is students with one year of physics and a minimum of Calculus 1.

Intellectual Merit: The goals of the three year project are the following: (1) Increase student learning in physics content areas that are chosen because there is either a lack of suitable material on the topic or because students exhibit alternate conceptions on the physics; (2) Enhance students' attitudes and beliefs about physics and learning physics and encourage increased enrollment in upper-division physics courses, especially by women; and (3) Increase student understanding of the scientific process through an engaged learning process - asking questions, analyzing data, drawing conclusions.

Broader Impacts: The project contributes to STEM education through its creation of new learning materials guided by research on teaching and learning in POM and designed to deal with areas in which students need to strengthen their physics understanding. The transformative nature of the project is inherent in the design of the POM Program with active learning and curricula related to students' interests in medicine. This approach enables students to make interdisciplinary connections, enhance conceptual understanding, and analyze quantitatively. Data from the project are contributing to the STEM body of knowledge on the performance of students (content/attitude) in upper division physics courses that apply physics principles to the medical field. This project broadens the participation of underrepresented groups by increasing the number of minors and potential majors in physics, and by increasing the underrepresented female student population in physics. Project modules are designed to be transferable to other universities with complete instructor manuals for easy implementation in different programs. Materials are being disseminated on the web and ComPADRE and through publications and presentations. By implementing well-designed, relevant, and interesting physics courses, the POM program can be sustainable. As a benefit to society, this project can lead to a better prepared generation of healthcare professionals and well-educated scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Starting with the X-ray in the 1900s, new diagnostic and therapeutic instrumentation have been developed which have transformed the health professions. These instrumentation include laparoscopes, MRI, CT, PET, gamma camera, ultrasound imaging, among others. In 2012, Loyola University Maryland and Rockhurst University received a collaborative grant to foster an understanding of the physics underlying these techniques and the human body. Specifically we developed teaching modules on: (1) fiber optics for light delivery and imaging; (2) pressure in the human body pertaining to lungs, alveoli, and the cardiovascular system; and (3) the gamma camera which utilizes radioisotopes for imaging. The curriculum materials are algebra-based and target undergraduates who have had 1-2 semesters of introductory physics. Some of the materials have been extended for advanced physics majors. These areas where chosen for their importance in healthcare, the richness of physics, a lack of curricular material at the appropriate physics level, and students' exhibition of alternate conceptions based on classroom analysis of student learning.

Four modules have been classroom-tested and presented in conferences and workshops. Instructional materials for fiber optics, lungs and alveoli are available in an online repository. These materials have been written with an inquiry-based pedagogy and hands-on activities to enable active-learning in the classroom. The understanding of physics principles is accomplished through medical case studies, videos, questions, and homework problems. Learning objectives and matched assessment questions are included for each section. For the cardiovascular system and the gamma camera, we are currently working on refining the instructional materials, and anticipate publishing on at least one of these modules within a year.

With the world increasingly dependent on the technology and projections of a severe shortage of qualified STEM professionals in the US, there is a need for people who are more knowledgeable in physics. At Loyola, one of the aims of introducing physics of medicine into the curriculum is to attract new types of students into studying physics-related topics. The NSF grant enabled the PI to develop two new upper-division (300-level) physics courses covering physics of the human body and medical instrumentation. The applied nature and active-learning pedagogy make these courses different from standard physics courses. In Spring 2016, these physics of medicine courses led to the establishment of a minor in "biomedical physics" at Loyola. The PI hopes that this minor will encourage other interdisciplinary science courses and programs at Loyola, enhance students' quantitative understanding of science and technology, and introduce students to fields that combine physics with medical applications.
